docs.title: Tabular2MCAP
docs.text: Convert tabular data (CSV, Parquet) to MCAP format with support for ROS2 and JSON schemas, enabling seamless integration with robotics workflows, data visualization in Foxglove Studio, and playback of sensor and navigation data.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Multi-Format Support: Convert to ROS2 or JSON messages with support for standard message types (e.g., sensor_msgs/msg/NavSatFix, geometry_msgs/msg/TransformStamped, foxglove.LocationFix, and more)
  • Configuration-Driven: YAML-based mapping with Jinja2 templates for flexible data transformation
  • Batch Processing: Process multiple files and directories with a single command

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: pip install tabular2mcap

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
tabular2mcap \
  -i /path/to/csv/files \
  -o output.mcap \
  -c config.yaml \
  -f converter_functions.yaml

docs.title: Configuration System
docs.text:
The tool uses YAML configuration files to define how CSV files should be processed. These are:

  • config.yaml: Defines file patterns and converter function mappings
  • converter_functions.yaml: Contains Jinja2 templates for data transformation

docs.title: Example Configurations
docs.text:
JSON Format: 

# config.yaml
writer_format: "json"
file_mappings:
  - file_pattern: 'data.csv'
    converter_functions:
      - function_name: "row_to_foxglove_location_fix"
        schema_name: "foxglove.LocationFix"
        topic_suffix: "LocationFix"

ROS2 Format: 

# config.yaml
writer_format: "ros2"
tabular_mappings:
  - file_pattern: '**/data.csv'
    converter_functions:
      - function_name: "row_to_nav_sat_fix"
        schema_name: "sensor_msgs/msg/NavSatFix"
        topic_suffix: "NavSatFix"

docs.title: Tutorial
docs.text: For detailed instructions on adding support for new types of CSV data, see the Tutorial in the documentation.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Thank you for contributing! Here's how to get started.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
# Install dependencies
uv sync --group dev

# Install pre-commit hooks
uv run pre-commit install

docs.title: Tests
docs.text:
uv run pytest                    # Run all tests
uv run pytest --cov=tabular2mcap # With coverage

docs.title: Linting & Formatting
docs.text:
uv run ruff check . --fix        # Lint and auto-fix
uv run ruff format .             # Format code

docs.title: Type Checking (optional)
docs.text: uv run mypy tabular2mcap/ --ignore-missing-imports

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
uv sync --group docs             # Install docs dependencies
uv run mkdocs serve              # Preview at localhost:8000

docs.title: Foxglove JSON Schema Updates
docs.text:
JSON schemas are included in the repo to avoid download caching. To update to the latest version: 

cd tabular2mcap/external
uv run python update_foxglove_schema.py

docs.title: Pull Request Process
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository and create a feature branch
  2. Make changes following the code style below
  3. Add tests for new features
  4. Run ruff check . --fix && ruff format .
  5. Push and open a PR with a clear description

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text:
• Line length: 88 characters
  • Quotes: Double quotes
  • Imports: Auto-sorted by Ruff
  • Type hints: Encouraged

docs.title: CI Requirements
docs.text:
PRs must pass:

  • ✅ Ruff linting and formatting
  • ✅ Tests on Python 3.10, 3.11, 3.12
  • ✅ Tests on Ubuntu, macOS, Windows

docs.title: Questions?
docs.text: Open an issue if you need help!

docs.title: Tutorial: Adding Support for New CSV Data Types
docs.text:
This tutorial walks you through the process of creating the config and converter files to support new types of CSV data.

The converter_functions.yaml is first created to reflect the column headings of the target CSV file, then the config.yaml file is created to the data in the target CSV to the convert functions in converter_functions.yaml.

docs.title: Step 1: Analyze Your CSV Data
docs.text:
The first step is to examine your CSV file structure to understand the data format:

# Look at the first few rows and data types
python -c "import pandas as pd; df = pd.read_csv('your_data.csv'); print(df.dtypes); print(df.head())"

docs.title: Step 2: Create Converter Functions
docs.text:
Create a converter_functions.yaml file with Jinja2 templates.

The strings sensor_columnX should be drawn from the column names found from Step 1, and sensorX is the label that the data will have in the final MCAP file. It may be necessary to cast your data to an int or float which can be done with | int and | float respectively.

# converter_functions.yaml
functions:
  sensor_data_to_foxglove:
    description: "Convert sensor readings to Foxglove format"
    template: |
      {
        "timestamp": {{ timestamp | int }},
        "frame_id": "{{ frame_id | default('sensor') }}",
        "sensor1": {{ sensor_column1 }}
        "sensor2": {{ sensor_column2 }}
      }

  gps_to_location_fix:
    description: "Convert GPS coordinates to Foxglove LocationFix"
    template: |
      {
        "timestamp": {{ timestamp | int }},
        "frame_id": "{{ frame_id | default('gps') }}",
        "latitude": {{ latitude | float }},
        "longitude": {{ longitude | float }},
        "altitude": {{ altitude | float | default(0) }},
        "position_covariance": [0,0,0,0,0,0,0,0,0],
        "position_covariance_type": 0
      }

docs.title: Step 3: Create Configuration File
docs.text:
Now the converter functions have been established in Step 2, the data in the target CSV must be mapped to those functions. This is done by creating a config.yaml file as shown below:

# config.yaml
writer_format: "json"

tabular_mappings:
  - file_pattern: "sensor_*.csv"
    converter_functions:
      - function_name: "sensor_data_to_foxglove"
        schema_name: "foxglove.RawMessage"
        topic_suffix: "SensorData"
        exclude_columns: ["unused_column"]

  - file_pattern: "gps_*.csv"
    converter_functions:
      - function_name: "gps_to_location_fix"
        schema_name: "foxglove.LocationFix"
        topic_suffix: "LocationFix"

# Optional: Add attachments and metadata
attachments:
  - file_pattern: "*.jpg"
    mime_type: "image/jpeg"
  - file_pattern: "*.mp4"
    mime_type: "video/mp4"

metadata:
  - file_pattern: "config.txt"
    separator: "="

docs.title: Step 4: (Optional) Advanced Jinja2 Templates
docs.text:
Use Jinja2's templating features for complex data transformations:

functions:
  advanced_sensor_conversion:
    template: |
      {
        "timestamp": {{ timestamp | int }},
        "frame_id": "{{ frame_id | default('sensor') }}",
        {% if row.temperature is defined %}
        "temperature": {{ row.temperature | float }},
        {% endif %}
        "status": "{{ 'healthy' if row.error_code == 0 else 'error' }}",
        {% if row.raw_data is defined %}
        "raw_data": {{ row.raw_data | from_json | default([]) }},
        {% endif %}
        "metadata": {
          {% for key, value in row.items() %}
          {% if key.startswith('meta_') %}
          "{{ key[5:] }}": {{ value | tojson }}{% if not loop.last %},{% endif %}
          {% endif %}
          {% endfor %}
        }
      }

docs.title: Step 5: Run the Conversion
docs.text:
The conversion can now be executed using your custom configuration yaml files:

# Basic conversion
tabular2mcap -i /path/to/your/data -o output.mcap -c config.yaml -f converter_functions.yaml

# With topic prefix and test mode
tabular2mcap -i /path/to/your/data -o output.mcap -c config.yaml -f converter_functions.yaml -t "my_robot/" --test-mode

docs.title: Step 6: Validate Output
docs.text:
Foxglove is a capable tool to validate the conversion output is correct.

First, download and install Foxglove Studio. Then, using the below command, open the generated MCAP file in Foxglove Studio to validate your data conversion:

foxglove-studio output.mcap

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
1. Column name issues: The tool automatically sanitizes column names by replacing spaces with _ and removing special characters
  2. Data type conversion: Use Jinja2 filters like | float, | int, | tojson for proper type conversion
  3. Missing data: Use <column_name> or 0 filter to handle missing values

docs.title: register_foxglove_schema(writer, schema_name)

MCAP writer instance

Name of the Foxglove schema (e.g., "LocationFix")

required

Returns:

Type Description int

Schema ID for use in channel registration

docs.text:

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default writer Writer

MCAP writer instance

required schema_name str

Name of the schema (e.g., "LocationFix")

required columns list[tuple[str, Any]]

List of (key, dtype) tuples for schema generation

required

Returns:

Type Description int

Schema ID that was registered

Name of the schema (e.g., "LocationFix" for Foxglove)

required

Returns:

Type Description int

Tuple of (schema_id, convert_row_function)

docs.title: write_messages_from_iterator(writer, iterator, topic_name, schema_id, data_length=None, unit='msg')
docs.text:
Write messages from a DataFrame with flexible conversion options.

This function can handle both Foxglove-specific schemas and generic JSON schemas by using different conversion strategies.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default writer Writer

MCAP writer instance

required iterator Iterable[tuple[int, dict]]

Iterable of tuples containing the index and message

required topic_name str

Full topic name for the messages

required schema_id int | None

Schema ID from register_foxglove_schema

required

Specialized Jinja2 environment for ConverterFunction that provides math functions, custom filters, and disables autoescape for JSON-like output.

docs.title: Data Models
docs.text: Pydantic models for configuration and converter functions.

docs.title: Main API
docs.text: High-level functions for converting tabular data to MCAP format.

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
The conversion process uses three main components:

  1. loader - Loads data and configuration files
  2. schemas - Manages and writes message schemas to MCAP
  3. converter - Transforms data into the target message format (JSON or ROS2)

docs.title: tabular2mcap.convert_tabular_to_mcap(input_path, output_path, config_path, topic_prefix, converter_functions_path, test_mode=False)
docs.text:
Convert tabular and multimedia data to MCAP format.

This is a convenience wrapper around the McapConverter class. For more control, use McapConverter directly.

docs.title: tabular2mcap.McapConverter
docs.text: Main class for converting tabular and multimedia data to MCAP format.

docs.title: __init__(config_path, converter_functions_path)
docs.text:
Initialize the MCAP converter.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default config_path Path

Path to the configuration file

required converter_functions_path Path

Path to the converter functions file

required

docs.title: convert(input_path, output_path, topic_prefix='', test_mode=False)
docs.text:
Convert tabular and multimedia data to MCAP format.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default input_path Path

Path to the input directory

required output_path Path

Path to the output MCAP file

required topic_prefix str

Prefix for topic names

'' test_mode bool

If True, limits data processing for testing

False

docs.title: tabular2mcap.schemas.cache
docs.text:
Script to download and cache ROS 2 message definitions from official repositories.

This script downloads the following repositories for a specified ROS 2 distribution: - rcl_interfaces - common_interfaces - geometry2

The downloaded files are cached in the user's cache directory to avoid re-downloading.

docs.title: download_and_cache_all_repos(distro='jazzy', cache_dir=None)
docs.text:
Download and cache all ROS 2 message definition repositories.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default distro str

ROS 2 distribution name (default: "jazzy")

'jazzy' cache_dir Path | None

Cache directory path (default: uses platformdirs cache)

None

Returns:

Type Description bool

True if all repositories downloaded successfully, False otherwise
